thread.title: Dirty Dancing actress proves 'nobody puts Baby in a corner' as she protests at anti Trump rally
thread.title_full: Dirty Dancing actress proves 'nobody puts Baby in a corner' as she protests at anti Trump rally

author: Jessica Gibb
title: Dirty Dancing actress proves 'nobody puts Baby in a corner' as she protests at anti Trump rally
text:
Dirty Dancing actress proves 'nobody puts Baby in a corner' as she protests at anti Trump rally Jennifer Grey wore a T-shirt that read: “Nobody puts p***y in a corner” Share Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Dirty Dancing star Jennifer Grey dances at Women's Protests Share this video   
She played one of cinema’s most iconic women in the 1980s, and now Dirty Dancing star Jennifer Grey is taking a stand for women’s rights. 
Because as her T-shirt read: “Nobody puts p***y in a corner.” 
The 56 year old joined the Women’s March in LA on Saturday and danced alongside pop star Miley Cyrus. Jennifer Grey's T-shirt at the Women's March (Photo: Rex Features) T he iconic moment from the movie Dirty Dancing. (Photo: SWNS) 
The actress – who’s also known for her role in Ferris Bueller’s Day Off – took to the streets to march in protest of US president Donald Trump. 
Her homemade T-shirt was a clever wordplay on Patrick Swayze’s famous line: “Nobody puts Baby in a corner.” 
The edit was in reference to Trump’s now infamous “grab her by the p***y” remark. Jennifer Grey with fellow feminists Natalie Portman and Jane Fonda (Photo: WENN.com) 
She paired the custom tee with ripped skinny jeans and walking boots. 
She pranced around to Queen classic Under Pressure in a video shared on Instagram with her 43.8k followers. 
Jennifer was joined by other A-listers taking a stand at the LA rally including Kerry Washington, Jane Fonda and Natalie Portman. Jennifer Grey went to the Women's March in Los Angeles (Photo: Getty) 
Millions of women across the globe took to the streets to march against Donald Trump yesterday in protest to his anti-female policies. 
In Washington DC, 500,000 turned out to stand up for gender equality, healthcare for women and other issues thought to be threatened under Trump's presidency. 
Across the US, a staggering 2.9million people showed up to support the cause - making history with the number of turnouts. 
And in London, 100,000 people took over the capital to raise banners, flags and their voices against the President of the USA. Like us on Facebook
